persona.name: Alexis Romero Aguilar

occupation.title: Social Media & Community Manager / Cultural Producer (part-time with freelance gigs)
occupation.organization: La Casa Cultural Colectiva (small non-profit cultural space) + freelance graphic design and events work
occupation.description: Formally employed part-time as Social Media & Community Manager at a neighborhood cultural space that runs workshops, concerts and micro-festivals. Responsibilities include: planning and executing social media campaigns (Instagram, TikTok, Facebook), community engagement (WhatsApp groups, mailing lists), event programming coordination, volunteer management, light budgeting and reporting for municipal cultural grants, coordinating with local musicians and artists, and on-site logistics during events. Outside that role she freelances as a graphic designer for small businesses, DJs at local bars/festivals occasionally, and sells zines and prints through an online shop. Her employment is a hybrid of formal part-time contract and informal freelance work; she invoices clients irregularly and sometimes receives cash payments for weekend gigs. Key skills used professionally: content strategy, copywriting in Spanish and some English, basic social analytics (Meta Business Suite, Canva analytics, Google Analytics lite), Adobe Illustrator/Photoshop, event logistics, small-scale grant applications, negotiation with vendors, and light audio mixing for DJ sets. Main occupational challenges: irregular income, navigating bureaucracy for cultural permits, balancing creative work with administrative reporting, and finding health insurance continuity between jobs.

persona.education: Bachelor's in Comunicación (Media and Cultural Management), Facultad de Ciencias Políticas y Sociales, UNAM. Graduated 2023. Thesis on community-driven cultural programming and social media as tools for local cultural participation. Completed internships at a small cultural NGO and a digital agency; attended short courses in Adobe Creative Suite and community-organizing facilitation.
long_term_goals: Build a sustainable career combining cultural programming, community-building and digital storytelling so she can keep producing local events and projects without depending solely on gig income.

Help expand accessible public cultural spaces in Mexico City outside the downtown neighbourhoods; create a mobile cultural outreach program that brings music, film nights and workshops to peripheral boroughs.
Be financially stable enough to buy a modest apartment or invest in a cooperative housing project with friends.
Start a small creative collective/brand that supports young mestizo artists and designers and reinvests profits into art education scholarships.
Learn to produce short documentary films and have a short documentary screened at a Mexican cultural festival.
Develop a consistent savings and retirement plan (first time thinking seriously about retirement savings and health insurance continuity).
Travel to two South American countries and one European city every few years — prioritizing cultural exchange and artist residencies over tourism.
Become a credible voice in media about cultural policy, urban life and youth perspectives, occasionally advising municipal cultural initiatives.
persona.style: Warm, fast-speaking and animated; typical central Mexican (chilangx) accent with quick intakes of breath and rising intonation at the end of excited sentences. Uses slang like "chingón/chévere", "buena onda", "neta", and code-switches to English for tech terms and jokes. Speaks with hands and facial expressions; often laughs while explaining things. In public interactions she is informal but polite — calls older professionals "usted" at first then quickly shifts to "tú" when the relationship warms. Online tone: playful, ironic, uses memes, gifs, emojis (💥🎧📸❤️) and short-form videos; captions are concise and conversational, often tagging collaborators and using local hashtags. Offline demeanor: energetic and social, likes to host small group dinners, greets acquaintances with a hug or cheek kiss, late riser on weekends, tends to arrive fashionably late to events. Personal presentation: eclectic streetwear mixed with thrifted vintage pieces and occasional garments by local designers; prefers practical bag (canvas tote/backpack) with chargers, notebook, reusable water bottle and compact film camera. Polite but direct in negotiations; expects clear timelines and fair payment for freelance work and will follow up persistently by message if needed.

traits: Curious and experimental — loves trying new music, formats and creative techniques.
Social and outgoing — recharges by being around diverse groups of people and attending events.
Empathetic — sensitive to friends' struggles and often acts as an emotional confidant.
Pragmatically idealistic — holds progressive values but recognizes trade-offs in day-to-day survival.
Flexible and adaptable — comfortable switching roles from admin work to creative production.
Slightly impulsive with money — often spends on experiences, gigs or travel before saving.
Moderately organized — keeps shared calendars and notes but can miss small administrative details.
Resilient — recovered from job instability during the pandemic and learned to diversify income.
Anxious about economic stability — worries about health insurance, rent, and unstable freelance payments.
Playful sense of humor — uses sarcasm and pop-culture references to defuse tension.
Values authenticity — dislikes performative activism and superficial branding.
Community-oriented — invests time in local groups and mutual aid networks.

big_five_descriptions.openness: Very high — voracious consumer of art, music, travel and new ideas; enjoys experimentation and learning.
big_five_descriptions.conscientiousness: Moderate — reliable for others, keeps essential systems (calendar, invoices), but procrastinates on paperwork and tax filing.
big_five_descriptions.extraversion: High — socially energized by events, maintains a wide network of acquaintances and collaborators.
big_five_descriptions.agreeableness: High — cooperative and helpful, but will push back when principles or payment fairness are at stake.
big_five_descriptions.neuroticism: Moderate — experiences stress about finances and uncertain futures, but uses social support and creative outlets to cope.

interests: Live music (indie, cumbia sonidera blends, experimental electronic sets)
Local festivals and barrio cultural fairs (Vive Latino attendance aspirations, smaller local micro-festivals)
Street photography and shooting 35mm film
Podcasts about urban culture, feminist theory and independent music scenes
Graphic design, zine-making and DIY print culture
Short documentary and experimental video
Traveling by bus to regional cultural hubs: Oaxaca, Guadalajara, Puebla
Cafés and coworking spaces with good Wi-Fi where she can both meet people and work
Thrift shopping and upcycling clothes
Attending political/artist talks and university lectures
Cooking quick regional dishes for friends
Curating playlists — enjoys sharing thematic playlists for friends and events
Learning basic audio production for her DJ sets and podcasts
Joining and organizing mutual aid and neighborhood solidarity initiatives
Following local journalists and critical cultural commentators on social media
Collecting vinyl records of Mexican and Latin American artists
Watching independent Mexican cinema and short films at community screenings
Experimenting with zine layouts and risograph printing
Volunteering at occasional cultural education workshops for youth
Participating in artist residencies or exchange programs when possible
likes: Tacos al pastor from a trusted fonda (prefers a particular stall near Coyoacán)
Coffee: café de olla or a strong americano; iced lattes for hot days
Street food snacks like esquites and tlacoyos during night events
Venues with inclusive and relaxed vibes (low-door-price, all-ages friendly)
Independent bookstores and second-hand record stores
Late-night conversations over cheap mezcal or micheladas
Aesthetic Instagram feeds that feel personal rather than polished
Small-batch Mexican craft coffee roasters and local bakeries
Artisan jewelry and accessories bought from markets or friends
Spotify for playlists, YouTube for tutorials and discovery, TikTok for quick trends
Analog photography labs that still do C-41 and black-and-white processing
Collaborative projects and community co-ops
Events that support emerging artists and pay modest fees
Reusable water bottles and sustainable product swaps
Wearing a favorite old denim jacket patched with pins and stickers
Podcasts in Spanish about culture, feminism, and urban policy
Playlists mixing classic boleros, norteno, indie rock and modern electronic remixes
Open mic nights where friends perform poetry or short sets
Meaningful, handwritten notes or zines given as gifts
Discounted student or local rates for museums and cultural spaces
dislikes: Overly corporate cultural sponsorships that erase local voices
Performative activism or token gestures without structural change
Tourist traps that fetishize indigenous culture without benefit to communities
Long administrative forms and bureaucracy for small grants
Poorly managed events with long lines and no accessibility considerations
Platforms that constantly change algorithms to prioritize paid content
Elitist art spaces that make newcomers feel unwelcome
Eating alone in sterile, expensive cafes with pretentious service
People who consistently fail to pay collaborators on time
Being gaslit about her time or contributions in collective projects
Aggressive or misogynistic behavior in nightlife spaces
Heavy-handed censorship or demonetization of critical voices online
Climate denial and apathy toward pollution in the city
Gentrification that displaces long-term neighbors
Condescending comments about "only doing creative things" as not real work
Payment platforms with high fees that eat her small earnings
Long commutes with unreliable public transport
Closed-mindedness about Mexico's indigenous cultural contributions
People who refuse to recycle or reduce single-use plastics
Overly polished influencer culture that feels inauthentic
food_and_drink_details: Breakfast: pan dulce with café de olla when at home, otherwise a torta or fruta from the mercado
Favorite snack: esquites with extra chile and lime
Comfort food: arroz con pollo or sopa de fideo made by her mother
Drink preferences: mezcal on special nights, michelada on warm afternoons, enjoys craft cerveza occasionally
Dessert: flan casero or churros with chocolate
Café habits: prefers small, independent cafés with tables and outlets; brings a reusable cup when possible
Cooking style: quick, improvisational, blends regional recipes with modern twists
Dietary notes: not vegetarian but eats mainly plant-forward; occasionally indulges in street meat
Eating out: chooses vendors that use biodegradable plates when available
Grocery preferences: buys fresh produce from the neighborhood market and supports local vendors
digital_and_tech_preferences: Primary phone: recent mid-range Android with good camera
Most-used apps: Instagram (for posting), WhatsApp (daily communication), TikTok (trend discovery), Spotify (music), Twitter/X (news and commentary), Telegram for some group chats
Content creation tools: Canva for quick posts, Adobe Illustrator/Photoshop for paid design work, InShot and CapCut for short video edits
Streaming: Spotify playlists, Netflix for films, YouTube for tutorials and discovery
Work tools: Google Workspace (Docs, Sheets), Trello or Notion for project tracking, Meta Business Suite for ad & post scheduling
Privacy preferences: uses two-factor authentication, avoids sharing sensitive financial info in chats, skeptical of platform data practices
Payment platforms: uses Mercado Pago, sometimes PayPal for international clients, bank transfers for formal contracts
Device habits: always carries a power bank; checks phone first thing in the morning; disables non-essential notifications during deep work
Collaboration: prefers asynchronous communication with clear deadlines, uses voice notes on WhatsApp for quick confirmations
music_and_culture_preferences: Favorite local acts: emerging indie bands from the CDMX scene, sonidero collectives remixing cumbia, and female electronic producers
Festival wishlist: Vive Latino, festival de cine alternativo, local barrio micro-festivals
DJ style: blends old cumbia, synthpop, reggaeton cuts and indie remixes for dancing crowds
Record collecting: favors regional labels, limited-press cassettes and Mexican punk reissues
Dance: enjoys dancing freely rather than following choreographies; likes crowded, sweaty dance floors
Visual art: contemporary muralism, street art and small gallery shows that feature local voices

beliefs: Universal healthcare is a human right and the government should expand public health services for all.
Public investment in education and arts is essential to reduce inequality and create social mobility.
Government should play an active role in redistribution and social programs; market solutions alone won't fix inequality.
Supports Morena's emphasis on social programs but remains critical of institutional corruption and lack of local accountability.
Local cultural spaces should be publicly funded and community-directed rather than beholden to corporate sponsors.
Trust in government institutions is limited due to repeated scandals and poor implementation, but civic engagement can improve outcomes.
Corruption is the main obstacle to effective social programs and must be tackled transparently.
Grassroots community organizing is more effective for immediate change than waiting for distant bureaucrats.
Police forces need reform; public security should include social and economic prevention, not only repression.
Gender equality requires structural change in workplaces, public spaces and cultural representation.
Trans and LGBTQ+ rights are human rights; public policy should protect minorities and ensure safe public spaces.
Indigenous cultures should be recognized, consulted and included in cultural policy, with material support rather than tokenization.
Climate change is urgent; urban policy should prioritize green public transport, bike lanes and air-quality measures.
Gentrification is harming neighbourhoods; cultural programming should not be an excuse to displace residents.
Support for small local businesses and cooperative models over large corporate chains in neighbourhood economies.
Digital platforms concentrate power and harvest user data; users should have more control and platform accountability is needed.
Art and culture have intrinsic value beyond immediate profitability and deserve public subsidy.
Creative labor is real labor and should be compensated fairly, with contracts and social protections whenever possible.
Mental health services should be publicly available and destigmatized, with community-based options.
Youth voices should be included in municipal decision-making, especially on culture, mobility and housing.
Education should include media literacy and critical thinking to help citizens navigate misinformation online.
Vaccination and public-health campaigns must be supported by accessible information and community outreach.
Mexico should invest in regional connectivity and cultural exchange, not only centralizing resources in the historic center.
Immigration is complex; borders should be managed with human rights in mind and local support systems for migrants created.
Economic policy should prioritize job quality and secure contracts rather than only GDP growth.
Small-scale entrepreneurship needs access to low-interest credit and training, not just rhetoric about startups.
Technology is a tool that can democratize culture if designed with inclusivity and public benefit as priorities.
Privatization of essential services often leads to reduced access; public options should remain strong and well-funded.
Art education and free access to cultural resources for kids in lower-income neighbourhoods is a priority.
Electoral engagement matters even when institutions disappoint; abstention leaves power to the organized few.
Civic transparency — open data about cultural spending and grant allocation — is necessary to reduce nepotism.
Solidarity networks (neighbourhood funds, mutual aid) are essential safety nets in crisis moments.
Fiscal policy should tax wealth more progressively to finance healthcare, education and cultural programs.
Local governments should be measured by lived improvements (clean air, accessible libraries, safe plazas) not only by headline spending.
International cultural exchange should be reciprocal and avoid extractive practices.
People in creative sectors should unionize or form cooperatives when possible to negotiate better terms.
Public spaces should be safe for women and non-binary people; lighting, services and respectful crowds matter.
Personal data collected by social apps needs legal protections and user rights regarding deletion and portability.
skills: Content strategy and community management (Instagram, TikTok, Facebook pages, WhatsApp community groups)
Adobe Creative Suite (Illustrator, Photoshop; intermediate level) and Canva for fast turnaround work
Basic video editing for social media (InShot, CapCut, Premiere Rush), understands vertical formats
Event coordination and volunteer management for small cultural events: logistics, stage times, contracts with bands
Copywriting in Spanish; concise, conversational captions and event descriptions; some translation/editing of English copy
Basic social media analytics: reading engagement metrics, scheduling posts, running modest paid promotions
Photography (35mm film and digital) — framing, street portraiture, low-light concert photography
Basic audio mixing for DJ sets and running a small PA system (soundcheck, EQ adjustments)
Small grant writing and reporting for municipal cultural funds; comfortable producing short budgets
Negotiation with local vendors and venue operators, contracting freelance collaborators
Community facilitation: leading small workshops, zine-making sessions and youth activities
Basic HTML/CSS familiarity for editing small web pages and landing pages for events
Spreadsheet budgeting for events and personal finances (Google Sheets competency)
Comfortable public speaking for panel talks, cultural program presentations and small emcee duties
Language skills: native Spanish with conversational English useful for international exchanges and reading sources
Time management across multiple gigs using calendars, reminders, and simple project boards (Trello/Notion)
Basic self-production of zines: layout, print ordering, distribution in local stores and markets
Networking and relationship-building with local promoters, artists and cultural institutions
Organizing crowd-funding or pay-what-you-can models for community events
Mediating small team conflicts and making quick decisions onsite during events

general: Checks phone within five minutes of waking; first scroll is Instagram and WhatsApp
Prefers texting or voice notes over long phone calls for quick coordination
Carries a small analog notebook for notes and sketching layout ideas during commutes
Brings reusable container and cutlery when buying street food when possible
Often arrives late to meetups if work or transit intervenes; apologizes with a small gift like coffee
Likes to make quick playlists to set the mood for events or friend gatherings
Will step in to help friends or neighbours with errands in exchange for future favors
Frequently posts behind-the-scenes content during events; behaves performatively online but keeps private thoughts off-grid
Prone to binge-listening and will send 10-song playlist links to close friends
Uses humor and sarcasm to deflate awkward situations

morning: Wakes around 8:30–9:30 AM on weekdays, later on weekends depending on event nights
Checks messages and responds to urgent gig emails before getting out of bed
Grabs coffee from a nearby cafecito or brews quickly at home when time allows
Reviews the day’s schedule in Google Calendar and prioritizes three must-do tasks
Skips elaborate breakfasts on busy days and prefers a piece of fruit or pan dulce
workday: Splits time between remote content creation and on-site coordination at the cultural space
Mornings often dedicated to content scheduling, caption writing and image edits
Afternoons reserved for meetings with artists, sponsor calls or visiting vendors in person
Keeps a midday walk or quick mercado run to reset — usually buys fresh produce or a snack
Ends formal work hours responding to messages, sending invoices and updating event checklists
evening: Attends or works at events two to three nights a week; spends evenings networking and socializing
When not working, meets friends for dinner, goes to a small gig or attends a film screening
Winds down with a short DJ set practice at home or editing photos from the day
Falls asleep around midnight to 1:00 AM if the night included events
weekend: Saturdays: markets in the morning, studio time or freelancing in the afternoon, evening events
Sundays: recovery day — slow coffee, visiting parents or extended family, small creative projects, planning the week
Occasionally takes nearby bus trips to visit friends in Puebla or Oaxaca for a weekend residency or show
Participates in neighborhood community meetings or volunteer-run cultural activities once a month

health.physical: Generally good health, slender build, near-sighted (uses contact lenses and glasses), had chickenpox as a child, no chronic illnesses diagnosed. Seasonal allergies to pollen; moderate sensitivity to spicy food when stressed.
health.mental: Mild generalized anxiety, particularly around finances and deadlines. Manages with therapy sessions every 3–4 weeks (affordable community therapist), uses breathing exercises and running or dancing as coping mechanisms. Occasional low mood after intense work periods; has a supportive friend group and seeks professional help when needed.
health.substance_use: Social alcohol use (1–3 drinks on event nights), occasional cannabis in social contexts (rare, more for relaxation), does not smoke cigarettes regularly.
health.reproductive_health: Uses combined oral contraceptive pill; attends annual gynecological check-ups when finances permit.
health.fitness_and_diet: Incorporates walking and dancing as main physical activities; does yoga once a week with a community studio. Diet is varied, leans toward fresh market produce but also eats street food regularly.
health.medical_access: Has public-sector access through Seguro Popular-style programs intermittently via family coverage and maintains a small private insurance for urgent needs when able; primary complaint is inconsistent coverage when switching freelance and part-time roles.

relationships.name: María Elena Romero (mother)
relationships.description: Lives in a different neighborhood but close by; works part-time selling handmade crafts at the mercado. Warm, protective, cooks family recipes, emotionally supportive; helps occasionally with rent and childcare favors for neighborhood kids. Encouraged Alexis to study and is proud of cultural work.

relationships.name: Jorge Aguilar (father)
relationships.description: Construction supervisor in Estado de México, pragmatic and hardworking. More conservative politically but supportive; gives practical advice about money and home repairs. Relationship cordial but sometimes tense over career stability and creative choices.

relationships.name: Diego Romero Aguilar (younger brother)
relationships.description: Studying communications at a local college; close relationship, share films and playlists; sometimes helps with tech or social media projects. Lives at home with mother.

relationships.name: Lucía (roommate and friend)
relationships.description: Shared apartment in Coyoacán, works as a barista and occasional event volunteer. Co-runs a small zine stall with Alexis on weekends; reliable, energetic, often coordinates logistics together.

relationships.name: Mateo (colleague)
relationships.description: Programmer/tech-savvy friend who helps with website tweaks and ad tracking; they met during university and collaborate on freelancing projects.

relationships.name: Tania (childhood friend)
relationships.description: Has known Alexis since primary school, now works in a municipal office, often connects Alexis with contacts and municipal permit information. Trusted confidant.

relationships.name: Romantic status
relationships.description: Single, casually dating. Prefers low-pressure relationships that respect her work schedule; values emotional availability and shared cultural interests. Has had two short-term relationships since university; currently not seeking a long-term commitment but open to it when stable.

relationships.name: Professional network
relationships.description: Wide but shallow: many acquaintances across cultural spaces, promoters, musicians, small-label owners, independent curators, and a few NGO contacts who occasionally refer paid work.

other_facts: Grew up in a mixed working-class neighborhood on the southern edge of Mexico City; family of mestizo background with grandparents from Puebla and Hidalgo.
Childhood nickname was 'Lex' given by classmates in secundaria.
First exposure to community cultural programming was through a local youth music workshop at age 14; this inspired her interest in cultural management.
Attended high school programs focused on arts and media before entering UNAM.
Organized her first public event — a small open-mic and zine fair — at age 19 in a community plaza with a borrowed PA system.
Experienced job instability during the COVID-19 pandemic; lost several part-time gig opportunities and learned to diversify income through online sales of prints and zines.
Has a small collection of 35mm film cameras; prefers black-and-white film for portraits and keeps negatives in labeled envelopes.
Won a modest municipal cultural grant to fund a micro-festival in her neighborhood in her final year of university; the project paid local artists and taught her grant reporting basics.
Has a visible small tattoo on the inner wrist of a stylized cactus and cassette tape symbolizing roots in local music scenes and analog practices.
Speaks conversational English, enough to read press materials and collaborate with some international artists, but sometimes struggles with advanced legal or technical English.
Once traveled alone by bus to Oaxaca for a week-long residency with two friends; remembers the markets, mezcal tastings and a transformative community mural workshop.
Keeps a memory box with concert tickets, old zines, and polaroids from trips and events that shaped her early 20s.
Has a modest credit-card debt from purchasing a second-hand laptop and camera gear for freelance work; paying it down monthly but worries about interest.
Volunteer experience includes teaching a basic photography workshop for neighborhood teens and organizing a clothing swap to support a local mutual aid fund.
Collects mixtapes and shares them with friends via Spotify collaborative playlists; created a 'Barrio Nights' playlist used frequently at events she programs.
Her first paid DJ gig was at a friend's birthday party; she charges modestly now but negotiates for travel reimbursement and rider requests when possible.
Family rituals: Sunday dinners with extended family where traditional dishes are shared; Alexis is the one who documents and photographs these gatherings.
Has been part of a small feminist book club since university that meets monthly to discuss new essays, zines and local feminist practice.
Worries about long-term health coverage and is slowly researching options for a private insurance plan that covers dental and gynecological services.
Maintains an emergency savings account but it is underfunded — aims to reach three months' expenses saved within two years.

Dislikes long bureaucratic processes but respects civic institutions when they function well; kept records and receipts meticulously during grant reporting after a negative earlier experience with missing funds.
Has moderate stage fright but can MC small events effectively with preparation and cue cards.
Remembers a formative moment at a university assembly where student organizers successfully pushed for safer campus policies; she now values collective action's tangible results.
Once had an awkward public confrontation with an intoxicated patron at a venue and afterwards helped coordinate a small team to improve security and safety protocols for artists.
Knows how to rewire a basic soundboard and once saved a show by adjusting levels during a power fluctuation.
Enjoys crafting small physical zines and has a low-cost risograph printing relationship with a local print shop.
Has experimented with short-form documentary—shot a 12-minute piece about a local sonidero group that screened at a neighborhood cultural night.
Her social media handle incorporates a nickname and hometown number — used consistently across platforms for branding.
Values concrete reciprocation: when offering help to other creatives she expects timely acknowledgments or payment agreements rather than vague promises.
Feels pride in being a visible young mestizo woman active in cultural life; wants to mentor younger girls from her neighborhood who express interest in arts.
Has a friendship pact with two close friends to do a yearly trip together; next plan is a low-budget trip to Guadalajara to visit a small music festival.
Participated in a campus protest for reproductive rights during university; she organized directories of legal support services as part of the action.
Is cautious about signing up for long-term loans; avoids payday lenders and high-interest personal loans, prefers to crowd-fund specific small projects when needed.
Keeps a rotating set of side hustles: commissioned posters, event photography, DJ nights and occasional branded content for small local businesses.
Has been invited once to contribute to a municipal cultural policy workshop as a youth representative; hopes to be invited again with a formal stipend.
Her favorite book is a small collection of contemporary Mexican short stories that she lends frequently to friends; they tease her about never getting it back.
Feels deeply nostalgic about certain barrio corners that have been demolished for new constructions; documents them in a photo series and hopes to publish it as a zine.
Would be excited to teach a formal course in community cultural programming in the future and is saving short-course materials and exercises she can later adapt.
Keeps a small list of go-to vendors for events: a local taco stand, a sound tech, a lighting person and a florist who specializes in native flowers.
Has moderately strong social media presence: not influencer-level but recognized in the local cultural circuit; uses that visibility to help peers get gigs.
